explanation.title: What is ROAS?
explanation.p1: ROAS (Return On Ad Spend) measures the revenue generated for every dollar spent on advertising. A ROAS of 400% (or 4x) means you earn $4 for every $1 spent.
explanation.formula: ROAS = (Revenue from Advertising / Cost of Advertising) × 100

hero.title: The Media Buying Glossary
hero.subtitle: Decode online advertising jargon. From A/B Testing to ROAS, all definitions explained simply for marketers.

cpc.name: Cost Per Click (CPC)
cpc.definition: The amount you pay each time a user clicks on your ad. It’s the foundational metric for traffic-driving campaigns.

cpa.name: Cost Per Acquisition (CPA)
cpa.definition: The total cost to acquire a paying customer through a campaign. Calculated by dividing total cost by the number of conversions.

ctr.name: Click-Through Rate (CTR)
ctr.definition: The percentage of people who clicked on your ad after seeing it. A high CTR generally indicates a highly relevant ad for the targeted audience.

cpm.name: Cost Per Mille (CPM)
cpm.definition: Cost Per Thousand Impressions. The price you pay for your ad to be shown 1,000 times. Highly used in brand awareness campaigns.

roas.name: Return on Ad Spend (ROAS)
roas.definition: Measures the gross revenue generated for every dollar spent on a specific advertising campaign.

roi.name: Return On Investment (ROI)
roi.definition: Measures the net profitability of an action. Unlike ROAS, ROI includes all costs (product margins, tools, salaries), not just ad spend.

cac.name: Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)
cac.definition: Groups all expenses (marketing, sales, salaries) needed to acquire a new customer, divided by the number of acquired customers.

ltv.name: LifeTime Value (LTV)
ltv.definition: The estimated total revenue a customer will generate for your business throughout their entire relationship with you.

retargeting.name: Retargeting
retargeting.definition: An advertising technique specifically targeting users who have already interacted with your brand (visited site, added to cart without buying) to encourage them to convert.

lookalike.name: Lookalike Audience
lookalike.definition: An algorithm-generated audience (e.g., Meta Ads) that identifies new users sharing similar characteristics and behaviors to an existing customer list (source audience).

cpl.name: Cost Per Lead (CPL)
cpl.definition: The average cost to acquire a qualified prospect (lead) who filled out a form or left their contact info.

cpv.name: Cost Per View (CPV)
cpv.definition: The average amount paid each time a user watches your video ad (widely used on YouTube Ads).

rtb.name: Real-Time Bidding (RTB)
rtb.definition: The buying and selling of digital ad impressions via instantaneous auctions that happen in milliseconds.

dsp.name: Demand-Side Platform (DSP)
dsp.definition: A software used by advertisers to buy advertising space automatically across multiple ad networks at the same time.

ssp.name: Supply-Side Platform (SSP)
ssp.definition: A technology platform that enables web publishers to automatically sell their unsold ad spaces to advertisers.

cvr.name: Conversion Rate (CVR)
cvr.definition: The percentage of users who completed a desired action (purchase, sign-up) after clicking on an ad, compared to the total number of visits.

bounce_rate.name: Bounce Rate
bounce_rate.definition: The percentage of visitors who leave your website after viewing only one page, without interacting further (0 seconds spent).

utm.name: UTM Parameters
utm.definition: Text tags added to the end of a URL allowing analytics tools (like Google Analytics) to very precisely track the source and performance of a campaign click.

ad_fatigue.name: Ad Fatigue
ad_fatigue.definition: The drop in campaign effectiveness (and ROAS) that occurs when your target audience has seen the same ad too repeatedly.

broad_match.name: Broad Match
broad_match.definition: A targeting type on Google Ads where your ad can show for searches including misspellings, synonyms, or related searches.

negative_keyword.name: Negative Keyword
negative_keyword.definition: A word for which you specifically prevent your ad from showing, in order to avoid irrelevant and unnecessarily costly clicks.

impression.name: Impression
impression.definition: The raw number of times your ad was displayed and loaded on a screen for a user, regardless of whether it was clicked or not.

reach.name: Reach
reach.definition: The estimated total number of unique accounts / people who were physically exposed to your ad at least once during the campaign.

frequency.name: Frequency
frequency.definition: The average number of times a unique person from your target audience was exposed to your ad. Calculated as Impressions divided by Reach.

a_b_testing.name: A/B Testing
a_b_testing.definition: A highly popular experimentation method consisting of simultaneously comparing two versions of an ad (A and B) to mathematically determine which performs best.
